title: Don’t tell Barbara Frale
post: Dan, come on, Barbara Frale knew about this decades ago, the last Templar Grand Master Jacques de Molay left Athens for France to discuss plans for a new crusade with Pope Clement VI, whose God was not Baphomet! That was when Philippe le Bel grabbed the opportunity to arrest all the Templars and snatch their moneybags because his treasury was empty. An innocent victim of the king’s greed and ruthlessness, de Molay asked to face Notre Dame when tied to the stake.
author: Louis

title: Don’t tell Barbara Frale
post: The design for a proposed statue at the Oklahoma state Capitol has NOTHING to do with the head in semblance of baphomet Templar Knights were said to venerate. The word baphomet (my own etymology) comes from the Hebrew Ba-phéo-Emet, in Italian “é la bocca della verità”, “the word in his mouth is truth”. It refers (my own iconocryptology) to the Turin Shroud death mask-like/Holy Face of the Holy Mandylion-like/ Holy Face of Manoppello-like ancient marble mask with a hole in the mouth called “La Bocca della Verità”, The Mouth of Truth.
author: Max patrick Hamon

title: Don’t tell Barbara Frale
post: Or better said: it refer to La Bocca della Verità mask-like Turin Shroud Holy Face/Holy Face of the Holy Mandylion/ Holy Face of Manoppello/Holy Veronica.
author: Max patrick Hamon

title: Don’t tell Barbara Frale
post: The Knight Templars’ alleged idole in likeness of a Baphomet is a combination of both the Turin Shroud Face and the Holy Face of the Holy Veronica aka The Holy Face of the Manoppello Veil.
author: Max patrick Hamon

title: Don’t tell Barbara Frale
post: Archaeocryptollogicaly speaking, this is made pretty obvious when you make a comparative study of the two Holy Faces in light of the Bust of Christ depicted in the Templar oak panel from Templecombe.
author: Max patrick Hamon

title: Don’t tell Barbara Frale
post:
On July 3, 2012 at 12:02 pm, I wrote:
“writers (e.g., MARTIALIS Martial) used the Greek word sindon in Latin (sindon, is) as early as the 1st century CE in accounts of very fine linen, silk and sea Byssus veil (= Manoppello Veil aka Holy Veronica aka Holy Mandylion). In 4th century CE Latin (e.g., Vulgata), the same word comes to also refer to the burial of Rabbi Yeshua of the synoptic gospels (Matthew, Mark and Luke = Linen Shroud). The (deliberate?) confusion between Mandylion (very fine Byssus veil) and Sindon (Yeshua’s burial cloth) would then find here its (philo)logical explanation.”
author: Max patrick Hamon
